introduction.p:
The number one is important in algebra, it lets us do things like
5a \amp = 15 \frac{1}{5}\cdot 5 \cdot a \amp = \frac{1}{5} \cdot 15 1a \amp = 3 a \amp = 3.

task.p: What matrix do you think will act similarly in matrix algebra for 2\times 2 matrices? (The rule you are trying to mimic is the 1a = a step from the example with numbers above.)

introduction.p: Write I for your 2\times 2 matrix from part (a) (for the I in identity matrix).

task.p: Does IA=A work when A is every 2\times\ell matrix?
Does BI = B also work for every 2\times 2 matrix B? For every \ell\times 2 matrix B?
Extend: What is the 3\times 3 version of I? 4\times 4? n\times n?

introduction.p:
In the preamble to , there were two ingredients necessary to make the algebra work:
there is a special number 1 so that 1a=a for all numbers a; and
for a nonzero number like 5, there is a multiplicative inverse 1/5 so that (1/5)\cdot 5 = 1.
Multiplicative inverses are very useful in algebra, so we would also like to have them in matrix algebra.

task.p: Consider A = \left[\begin{array}{rr}0\amp-1\\1\amp2\end{array}\right]. Can you determine B = \begin{bmatrix}a \amp b\\c \amp d\end{bmatrix} so that BA = I? If so, check that AB = I also.

aside.p: Don't just guess at matrix B, use the definition of matrix equality applied to BA and I to set up equations and try to solve for unknown entries a,b,c,d.

task.p: Consider A = \begin{bmatrix}0 \amp 1\\0 \amp 0\end{bmatrix}. Can you determine B = \begin{bmatrix}a \amp b\\c \amp d\end{bmatrix} so that BA = I?

postlude.p: The previous activity demonstrates that some square matrices have multiplicative inverses ( are invertibleinvertible) and some do not (called singularsingular in this case). If square matrix A is invertible, write \inv{A} for its inverse. (But never write 1/A!) This inverse is defined by its relationship to A and I: \inv{A} is the square matrix of the same size as A so that both A\inv{A} = I and \inv{A}A = I are true.

aside.p: Do you understand why we must assert that both A\inv{A} = I and \inv{A}A = I are true in defining the inverse \inv{A}, not just one? Maybe look back at .

introduction.p: In the following, assume A,B,C are square invertible matrices, all of the same dimension, and assume that k is a nonzero scalar. Do not just look up the answers in the rest of this chapter, try to come up with them yourselves.

task.p: What do you think is the inverse of \inv{A}? Explain. (Your justification should mention the identity matrix.)
Determine a formula for the inverse of kA in terms of k and \inv{A}.
Explain why the formula for the inverse of AB is not \inv{A}\inv{B}. Then determine the correct formula.
Extend: What is the formula for the inverse of ABC?

What do you think A^{-2} means? There are two possibilities; do they both work out to the be same? Try with A given below. (For convenience, its inverse is also given.)
A \amp = \left[\begin{array}{rr} 0 \amp -1 \\ 1 \amp 2 \end{array}\right] \amp \inv{A} \amp = \left[\begin{array}{rr} 2 \amp 1 \\ -1 \amp 0 \end{array}\right]

statement.p:
In algebra, when AB=AC we would usually conclude that B=C. Try this out for the matrices below.
A \amp = \begin{bmatrix}0 \amp 1\\0 \amp 0\end{bmatrix} \amp B \amp = \begin{bmatrix}1 \amp 1\\2 \amp 3\end{bmatrix} \amp C \amp = \left[\begin{array}{rr} -1 \amp -1 \\ 2 \amp 3 \end{array}\right]
What is it about matrix A that is making the usual algebra of cancellation fail?

hint.p: Think about the hidden algebra behind the cancellation ab=ac\Longrightarrow b=c for numbers.

task.p: In what circumstance is the algebra AB=AC \implies B=C valid? What explicit algebra steps go into this deduction?
Is the algebra AB=CA \implies B=C ever valid?

activity.p: If we have a linear system A\uvec{x}=\uvec{b} with a square and invertible coefficient matrix A, we can use matrix algebra to solve the system instead of row reducing, by using \inv{A} to isolate \uvec{x}.

Here is an invertible 3 \times 3 matrix A and its inverse:
A \amp = \left[\begin{array}{rrr} 0 \amp 1 \amp -2 \\ 1 \amp 2 \amp 0 \\ -2 \amp -4 \amp 1 \end{array}\right], \amp \inv{A} \amp = \left[\begin{array}{rrr} -2 \amp -7 \amp -4 \\ 1 \amp 4 \amp 2 \\ 0 \amp 2 \amp 1 \end{array}\right].
Use matrix algebra (not row reducing!) to solve the system A\uvec{x} = \uvec{b} for \uvec{b} = \left[\begin{array}{r} -1 \\ 1 \\ 3 \end{array}\right]. Now use the same method to solve the system A\uvec{x} = \uvec{b} for \uvec{b} = \left[\begin{array}{r} -2 \\ 0 \\ 2 \end{array}\right].

statement.p: In general, for system A\uvec{x} = \uvec{b} with a coefficient matrix A that is square and invertible, how many solutions does the system have? Justify your answer.
